results:
Based on the search results, I found comprehensive information about Wojciech Charchalis and his work on Don Quixote in relation to Polish literary research. Here's what the search revealed:

Wojciech Charchalis is a Polish translator and lecturer at the Institute of Romance Philology at Adam Mickiewicz University in Poznań. He translates from Portuguese, Spanish and English.

He has translated works by authors such as Miguel de Cervantes (Don Quixote translation), Clarice Lispector, Mario Vargas Llosa, Javier Marias, Fernando Pessoa, Jose Saramago. He is the laureate of the Wisława Szymborska Award 2022 for the best translation of a poetry volume published in 2018-2021 into Polish (Heteronyms. Selected Works of Fernando Pessoa).

Regarding his Don Quixote work:

The work represents "the long-awaited first Polish critical edition of Don Quixote, in a new, excellent translation by Wojciech Charchalis". Charchalis dedicated five years to Cervantes' work, beginning the translation in February 2008.

There had been four previous complete Polish translations - two from French (one from the end of the 18th century, another from the mid-19th century) and two from Spanish, which were already very old and could be painful to read in modern times. Charchalis believed that a new translation of this masterpiece was absolutely necessary, describing it as "a kind of facelift, refreshing Don Quixote".

62 years had passed since the last Polish translation of Cervantes' work, making Charchalis's new translation particularly significant for Polish literary research and readership.

The search results show that Charchalis's work represents an important contribution to Polish Cervantes studies, providing a modern, accessible translation that captures the humor and linguistic variety of the original Spanish text, filling a significant gap in Polish literary translations.
